Posts.Content: Buttons2 wrote: If any of you have an opportunity to go to a Look Good Feel Better program from the American Cancer Society, I recommend it.  They teach you how to care for your skin during chemo and give you a makeup kit with all kinds of stuff in it to help conceal the effects of chemo if you have issues.  It was available for anyone going through chemo or someone who has been through chemo.  I haven't started my chemo yet and my mom just went through her second round with it so it was a learning experience for us both.  They also showed me diffent ways to wrap turbins and cute hair wraps and talked about wigs and their care.  I felt good about myself when I left so didn't my mom :) 1/11/2012 lumpectomy LCIS, then needle biopsy after breast mri and 2/17/2012 diagnosed w/mixed ductal & lobular cancer 3/6 BMX w tissue expanders, started chemo 4/6, last fill 5/15. Now to finish chemo & Radiation and have my exchange...Long Journey Dx 2/17/2012, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
